docs.lead_paragraph: Yonder white cottage opposite the church, and half hidden among those beautiful maples, is our country parsonage. Its occupant is Rev. Mr. JOHNSON, who, for twenty--five years past--quite a long time, by the way, in this day of frequent changes--has been our beloved pastor.

headline.main: MEMORIALS OF MR. WEBSTER; NUMBER THIRTEEN.

docs.lead_paragraph: **** At Pittsheld, Mr. FRANCIS GRAN??GER came into the cars as a passenger, and he too, was most rapturously cheered. Thus we came and arried here, at 8 1/2 o'clock. At the depot the crowd was immense.

headline.main: MR. THACKERSY'S LECTURES.; No. II.-Congreve and Addison.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. THASKERAY read his second lecture last evening to an audience which, in spite of the extreme inclemency of the weather, was still larger than the first.. His subject led him into a train of remark quite different from that of the former evening, and afforded no opportunity for the graphic sketches of passion which in that were so well calculated to enchain attention :-but his

docs.lead_paragraph: In Brooklyn, 21st inst. Mrs. ELIZABETH HIPWOOD MILFORD, relict of the late Edward Milford. The funeral will take place this (Tuesday) afternoon, at 1 o'clock from Grace Church, Brooklyn Heights. The friends of the family are requested to attend, without further invitation. At the residence of her son-in-law, Judge Morse, Brooklyn, N Y, on Sunday, 21st inst., Mrs. CHLOE TIFFANY, of Brooklyn, Conn., aged 72 years.

docs.lead_paragraph: It may not be generally known to the' people of the United States, that comprised within the limits of the good State of New-York, there are two Southports. One sufficiently well known lies in Connecticut, the other and more retiring Dromio is obscurely nestled upon a creek in Long Island.

headline.main: The Cherokee Nation-Messange of the Chief--Indian Government.
WILLIAMSBURG CITY.; FUNERAL OF CAPT. J. R. VAN RANST. SWINDLE IN COAL. DROWNNED. POLICE. SUDDEN DEATH. ROBBERY.

docs.lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OF CAPT. J. R. VAN RANST.-The funeral of Mr. VAN RANST, who died suddenly on Wednesday night last, took place from his late residence in North Second-street. at one o'clock yesterday afternoon. The procession, as it moved through Grand-street, was very imposing. The procession came in the following order:

docs.lead_paragraph: SWINDLING BY A SHIP'S CAPTAIN.--The policeof Paris arrested on Saturday the captain of an English merchant ship, the Shakspere, under the following circumstances: In March last the Shakspere left the port of Canton, having on board an American. This American was very badly off, and had no goods; but he and the captain concocted a scheme for committing a fraud on a grand scale.

headline.main: NORFOLK-STREET BAPTIST CHURCH.; Woman's Tongue." A LECTURE BY REV. THOMAS ARMITAGE.

docs.lead_paragraph: The membership of the Norfolk-street Baptist Church was formed some ten years since, and service held in a small building on the site of the Church now standing in Norfolk, near Broome-street. The present commodious and handsome edifice was erected about four years since, by Rev. THOMAS ARMITAGE,

docs.lead_paragraph: PLEASURES OF DISPENSING OFFICES.--The Hon. STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS, Senator of the United States, and prospective Secretary of State for the same, arrived at New Orleans yesterday morning, and departed in the afternoon per mail boat for Mobile, en route, it is supposed, for the Federal Metropolis.
